Award.AwardTitle: Middle Tennessee Mechatronics Engineering Scholars Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Middle Tennessee Mechatronics Scholars Program at Middle Tennessee State University (MTSU) plans to increase the number of students in the school's new Mechatronics Engineering baccalaureate degree program by 50% and retain at least 80% of incoming freshmen to the sophomore year. At least 15 new freshman majors will receive scholarships each year, allowing students to focus on their studies, complete college in four years instead of six, and give them two additional years of earnings and less debt. S-STEM scholarships will enable the program to recruit talented, dedicated students who will succeed in the rigorous engineering curriculum. The Tennessee automotive industry needs strong mechatronics engineers and this project will help meet this significant workforce need in Tennessee. The need for mechatronics engineering education is growing, not only in the middle Tennessee area, but also across the entire country as many mechatronics positions are seeking qualified applicants.

Opportunities for members of the cohort to participate in educational activities during their first year include a week long summer training experience at Siemens Headquarters in Berlin, Germany, a four week mechatronics research team project, intrusive advising, tutoring, mentoring, and manufacturing plant tours. Later, internships and significant interactions in the automotive manufacturing industry are possible. A dedicated professional advisor and predictive analytics software will enable project leaders to detect and address issues that place students at-risk. MTSU faculty and students will contribute to the engineering education literature related to early research experiences for engineering students, the impact of various support activities on the success of freshman engineering students, and the impact of hands-on project work on retention of female and minority engineering students. Comparing a) the building of a high quality engineering program using the Siemens systems approach and high level of student-industry interaction to b) a traditional engineering education will be a helpful contribution to the engineering education literature.

The mechatronics engineering majors at Middle Tennessee State University (MTSU) has been growing explosively in the past few years due to the high quality of the program as well as the strong regional demand. Middle Tennessee Mechatronics Engineering Scholars Program (MT2) helped us to recruit many talented individuals, especially female and minority students. Over a period of four years, the scholarship supported 31 students in the major. Meanwhile, the mechatronics major has grown from 237 in 2015 to 390 in 2018. Among which, the underrepresented group including the minority students and female students have grown from 73 to 123 and from 24 to 55 respectively. The freshmen retention rate has steadily increased to 80.7% by 2018, which is much higher than the university average.

 

We have provided strong academic support for the scholars. ACT-ENGAGE test was given to all incoming scholars to evaluate their self-confidence, work ethic, maturity and motivation. Monthly advising meetings with the scholars are offered by email or in person to provide timely guidance. The scholars are also introduced to additional supportive activities to help with their academic development along their undergraduate years. Plant tours to local manufacture companies including Nissan, Bridgestone, Schwan cosmetics, etc. are offered every semester, which exposed them to engineering/manufacturing opportunities at an early stage of their engineering education. Sponsored by the grant, eight students traveled to Germany to participate in a week-long training by Siemens. For research opportunities, some scholars attended summer research camp led by Dr. Hu. Not only they benefited from this opportunity, but up to 40 undergraduates from different majors in the College of Basic and Applied science also participated. The final research outcome is presented as a research seminar to the entire school. Others collaborated with Experimental Vehicle Program led by Dr.Foroudastan. Overall, it has improved retention, academic performance, and student?s readiness to pursue STEM careers and advanced degree in the major.

 

In the effort to recruit potential mechatronic scholars, the department established articulation agreement with several high schools and community colleges including Motlow Community College, Cleveland State Community College, Columbia State Community College, and Oakland high school. This allows easy path for the high school and community college students to pursue BS level mechatronics engineering degree at MTSU. 

 

To make a broader impact to the region and beyond, the outcome has been shared with our industrial advisory board and local companies including Nissan Automation, Davis Group, etc. We also shared the outcome with state and local legislators. Tennessee Governor Bill Lee visited the program and gave a speech to celebrate its success.
